title: Ghana: Ghana 'S Cyber Security Policy to Take Effect By September 2015
text:
Ghana 'S Cyber Security Policy to Take Effect By September 2015 Tagged: Nigeria: Army Captures Boko Haram Commander, Rescues 178 Captives in Bama Axis press release 
The Minister for Communications, Dr Edward Omane-Boamah, has hinted that Ghana's Cyber Security Policy would take effect by September this year. 
Speaking at a Stakeholders Forum to update the Draft Cyber Security Policy in Accra recently, the Minister said the spate at which the demand for internet service was running, the need for protection of the economy and the country's valuable asset was critical. 
He was of the view that, cyber security was of great essence not just to Ghana but globally as internet fraud was becoming twisted as one country could be used to hack into another country's security asset without the knowledge of the country concerned. Related Topics Nigeria: Army Captures Boko Haram Commander, Rescues 178 Captives in Bama Axis 
Dr Omane-Boamah indicated that cyber security policy called for international collaborations as the issue of internet hacking could not be handled by any one country; adding that with global alliance, human relations and the help of the security agencies, internet hacking could be combated. 
The Chief Executive Officer of Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers ( ICANN), Prof. Nii Narku Quaynor, suggested that after the launch of the policy document, there should be an annual review by stakeholders so that more expertise could be developed to match up to the internet fraud and to combat it. 
Prof. Quaynor said cyber security called for working in groups and encouraging collaborations, hence, the need for all stakeholders to come on board to implement the policy. 
The Cyber Security Policy and Strategy has eight pillars made up of effective governance, legislative and regulatory framework, research and development towards self-reliance, cyber security emergency readiness, cyber security technology framework, Culture of security and capacity building, compliance and enforcement as well as international cooperation. 
The policy encourages national cyber security awareness program, emergency response team which Dr Omane-Boamah stated was already in place. 
Source: ISD (Chantal Aidoo & David Amedalor) Ghana
